review.title: EEG Representation Using Multi-instance Framework on The Manifold of Symmetric Positive Definite Matrices for EEG-based Computer Aided Diagnosis
review.abstract: The generalization and robustness of an electroencephalogram (EEG)-based computer aided diagnostic system are crucial requirements in actual clinical practice. To reach these goals, we propose a new EEG representation that provides a more realistic view of brain functionality by applying multi-instance (MI) framework to consider the non-stationarity of the EEG signal. The non-stationary characteristic of EEG is considered by describing the signal as a bag of relevant and irrelevant concepts. The concepts are provided by a robust representation of homogenous segments of EEG signal using spatial covariance matrices. Due to the nonlinear geometry of the space of covariance matrices, we determine the boundaries of the homogeneous segments based on adaptive segmentation of the signal in a Riemannian framework. Each subject is described as a bag of covariance matrices of homogenous segments and the bag-level discriminative information is used for classification. To evaluate the performance of the proposed approach, we examine it in attention deficit hyperactivity/bipolar mood disorder detection and depression/normal diagnosis applications. Experimental results confirm the superiority of the proposed approach, which is gained due to the robustness of covariance descriptor, the effectiveness of Riemannian geometry, and the benefits of considering the inherent non-stationary nature of the brain.

sections.text: We propose a new representation of the non-stationary EEG signal, which should be robust and lead to an appropriate generalization of the diagnostic system (Fig. 1). In this section we first present our representation and then describe an EEG segmentation method.

sections.heading: A. MI representation of EEG signal
sections.text: Psychiatry is often used as an informative source of non-stationary EEG signals in CAD applications, and could be diagnosed by detecting specific patterns in the electrical activity of the patient. However, the other main sources of non-stationary signals are noise in the environment, artifacts and biological sources that inevitably affect the signal during recording. To represent the different segments of non-stationary signals, we must interpret the segmentation of subjects as a bag of different concepts. Here, concepts are the covariance matrices of homogeneous segments (in a statistical sense) resulting from the adaptive segmentation of EEG signals (Section III). sections.heading: IV. EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: In this section, we evaluate the proposed representation in two different applications for diagnosing psychiatric disorders: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) / Bipolar Mood Disorder (BMD) and Depression / Normal Group. We first describe the datasets and recording conditions of EEG signals for these two datasets, then describe various experimental setups and results, and finally discuss the results.

sections.heading: A. Data sets
sections.text: Specification and recording conditions of the records are described in detail as follows: 1) ADHD / BMD [36] ADHD and BMD are psychiatric disorders with similar clinical symptoms. The overlap between the clinical symptoms of these two disorders results in unreliability of the qualitative diagnostic approach. This record consists of the EEG signal of 43 children and adolescents, with 21 subjects with ADHD (age range: 10-20, age average ± std: 14.36 ± 2.9) and 22 subjects with BMD (age range: 13-22, age average ± std: 16.50 ± 2.50). Data collection was conducted at the Biophysics Laboratory of Shiraz University of Medical Sciences. Children, adolescents and at least one of their parents were interviewed with DSM _ IV criteria for diagnosis. It should be noted that most subjects were followed by psychiatrists for at least 6 months and the psychiatrist was insured about their type of disease.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we proposed a new representation to describe EEG signals. In this representation, we apply the MI framework to take into account the instationality of the EEG signal; the concepts in this representation are described by the empirical covariance matrix of the EEG segments, which are the result of the adaptive segmentation of the signal and all analyses are carried out within the Rieman framework. Using the MI core to describe the EEG signal is a suitable choice, which increases the discriminatory information by automatically attenuating the noise contribution (i.e. as a constant offset in the measure of similarity). Experimental evidence confirms the significant superiority of this representation in EEG-based CAD applications. This superiority results from considering the instationality of the EEG signal without the need for explicit induction of EEG segments, using the covariance matrix to describe the benefit of these segments, and examining the limitations of the covariance problems of the adaptation of the segments.

metadata.abstractText: Abstract—The generalization and robustness of an electroencephalogram (EEG)-based computer aided diagnostic system are crucial requirements in actual clinical practice. To reach these goals, we propose a new EEG representation that provides a more realistic view of brain functionality by applying multi-instance (MI) framework to consider the nonstationarity of the EEG signal. The non-stationary characteristic of EEG is considered by describing the signal as a bag of relevant and irrelevant concepts. The concepts are provided by a robust representation of homogenous segments of EEG signal using spatial covariance matrices. Due to the nonlinear geometry of the space of covariance matrices, we determine the boundaries of the homogeneous segments based on adaptive segmentation of the signal in a Riemannian framework. Each subject is described as a bag of covariance matrices of homogenous segments and the bag-level discriminative information is used for classification. To evaluate the performance of the proposed approach, we examine it in attention deficit hyperactivity/bipolar mood disorder detection and depression/normal diagnosis applications. Experimental results confirm the superiority of the proposed approach, which is gained due to the robustness of covariance descriptor, the effectiveness of Riemannian geometry, and the benefits of considering the inherent non-stationary nature of the brain.
